questions.question: Why does the poet call the butterfly near him? (Variant 51)
questions.answer: Because he wants to relive memories.

questions.question: What memories does the butterfly awaken? (Variant 52)
questions.answer: Memories of childhood and play.

questions.question: Who chased the butterfly with the poet? (Variant 53)
questions.answer: His sister Emmeline.

questions.question: Why was the poet like a hunter? (Variant 54)
questions.answer: He ran and leapt while chasing it.

questions.question: What does the butterfly symbolize? (Variant 55)
questions.answer: Childhood innocence and joy.

questions.question: Why is Emmeline mentioned in the poem? (Variant 56)
questions.answer: She shared his playful adventures.

questions.answer: Warmth, joy and remembrance.

questions.question: Why does the poet beg the butterfly not to fly away? (Variant 58)
questions.answer: Because it brings back precious memories.

questions.question: What is meant by 'dead times revive'? (Variant 59)
questions.answer: Old memories come alive again.

questions.answer: It looks backward lovingly at the past.

questions.question: Explain how the butterfly becomes a symbol of childhood in the poem. (Insight 151)
questions.answer: It represents simple joys, play and innocence that the poet shared with his sister while young.

questions.question: Discuss the emotions the poet experiences when seeing the butterfly. (Insight 152)
questions.answer: The poet feels joy, nostalgia and deep affection for his childhood days and lost family moments.

questions.question: Describe how Wordsworth and Emmeline behaved differently while chasing the butterfly. (Insight 153)
questions.answer: Wordsworth chased boldly like a hunter, while Emmeline was gentle and avoided hurting the butterfly.

questions.question: How does Wordsworth use memory and imagination to bring the past alive? (Insight 154)
questions.answer: By seeing the butterfly he relives scenes of play, laughter and emotions, making the past feel present.

questions.question: What is the central message of the poem? (Insight 155)
questions.answer: The poem teaches us to cherish childhood memories and recognise beauty in small natural experiences.
